issues.description: Constructor parameter order for Meal is inconsistent between the problem statement/UML and the template. The problem statement (UML) specifies Meal(String, String[]) but the template class Meal has the constructor Meal(String[] ingredients, String name) (parameters reversed). The template's Main also uses the Meal(String, String[]) form in its example instantiations, which will not match the template Meal constructor and will confuse students or cause compilation errors if they follow the problem examples. The solution repository uses the correct signature Meal(String, String[]).
issues.suggested_fix: Change the constructor in the template Meal class to match the specification and solution: public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) { this.name = name; this.ingredients = ingredients; }. Ensure the parameter order matches the UML and the example usages in Main.

issues.description: Constructor parameter order for Meal is inconsistent: the problem statement's class diagram and the solution use Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) (name first), but the template defines the constructor as Meal(String[] ingredients, String name) (ingredients first). This mismatches the documented API and the example usage in Main (which constructs Meal with name first), creating confusion for students about the correct constructor signature and leading to potential compile/runtime misunderstandings.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template Meal constructor to match the problem statement and solution: declare it as public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) and assign fields accordingly. Also ensure example usages in Main (and any tests) use the same parameter order.
